questions.text: A 28-year-old male with a history of chronic ear discharge and hearing loss undergoes an otoscopic evaluation. The image below shows a large central perforation of the tympanic membrane with visible middle ear structures. What is the most appropriate surgical intervention for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has features of Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) – Tubotympanic type, evidenced by:

  • Chronic ear discharge
  • Conductive hearing loss
  • Large central perforation of the tympanic membrane without cholesteatoma

The most appropriate surgical treatment is Tympanoplasty.

Tympanoplasty:

  • Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure aimed at repairing a perforated eardrum (tympanic membrane) and, in some cases, reconstructing the ossicles (the small bones in the middle ear) to restore hearing function. This surgery is commonly recommended when a perforation does not heal on its own, often due to chronic ear infections or trauma.
  • Anaesthesia: Typically performed under general anaesthesia
  • Surgical Approach: The surgeon may access the eardrum through the ear canal or make an incision behind or in front of the ear, depending on the location and size of the perforation.
  • Graft Material: A graft, often taken from the patient's tissue (such as fascia or cartilage), is used to patch the eardrum.
  • Additional Procedures: If the ossicles are damaged, procedures like ossiculoplasty (reconstruction of the ossicles) or mastoidectomy (removal of infected mastoid bone) may be performed concurrently.

The Wullstein classification categorizes the procedure based on the extent of the defect and the method of reconstruction.

Explanation of Other Options:

Atticotomy (Option A): Performed for attic cholesteatoma or retraction pockets in the pars flaccida. Not indicated in simple central perforation.

Modified radical mastoidectomy (Option B): Indicated in atticoantral disease (cholesteatoma type of CSOM) or unsafe ear. Not required in safe central perforation.

Myringoplasty (Option C): It only repairs the tympanic membrane without addressing ossicular continuity, making it inadequate in this case, where middle ear structures are exposed.

questions.text: An industrial worker presents with hearing loss. On examination, Rinne's test was negative on the left side and positive on the right side. Weber's test lateralized to the left side. Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) was done with the results as shown below. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis is a left conductive hearing loss, which is consistently supported by all the provided findings.

  1. Rinne's Test: A negative result on the left (Bone Conduction > Air Conduction) is the classic sign of a conductive hearing loss in that ear. The positive result on the right is normal.
  2. Weber's Test: The sound lateralizing to the left ear indicates a conductive hearing loss on that same side.
  3. Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA):
    • Right Ear: The audiogram shows hearing thresholds within the normal range (0-20 dB).
    • Left Ear: The audiogram shows normal bone conduction thresholds (upper line, squares) but significantly elevated air conduction thresholds (lower line, crosses). I.e., AC is poor, BC is normal. The difference between these two lines is the air-bone gap, which is the hallmark of a conductive hearing loss.
    • In SNHL, both AC & BC are poor

Explanation of Other Options:

Right conductive hearing loss (Option A): Incorrect, since Rinne's test was positive on the right and no air-bone gap on the right PTA.

Right sensorineural hearing loss (Option C): Incorrect, would cause Weber lateralization to the left, but Rinne would also be positive on the left, not negative.

Left sensorineural hearing loss (Option D): A left SNHL would present with a positive Rinne's test (as both AC and BC would be reduced), Weber's lateralizing to the right (better) ear, and an audiogram showing both air and bone conduction thresholds depressed together, with no significant air-bone gap.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 12-year-old male presents with recurrent, profuse nasal bleeding and right-sided nasal obstruction. Endoscopy reveals a globular, vascular mass in the right nasal cavity occupying the posterior choanae and nasopharynx. A CT scan shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The combination of clinical and radiological findings is pathognomonic for a Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA).

Angiofibroma:

  • The most common benign tumor of the nasopharynx
  • Arises from the sphenopalatine foramen
  • Exclusive in adolescent males

Clinical features

  • Presents with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction, hyponasality( Rhinolalia clausa)
  • On examination, a red and fleshy mass was seen in the nasal cavity
  • As Eustachian tube obstruction occurs, serous otitis media can occur, and the patient can present with conductive type hearing loss

The tumor can spread into

  • Laterally- pterygopalatine fossa, causing pressure over the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, causing it to bow anteriorly, called the Holman Miller sign or Antral sign, seen in contrast CT
  • Orbit- through the inferior orbital fissure, causing proptosis, diplopia, with involvement of II, III, IV, and VI cranial nerves, depending on the extent of the tumor
  • Infratemporal fossa- through the pterygomaxillary fissure, and appears as cheek swelling
  • Intracranial extension can occur

Nasal bridge broadening, proptosis, and cheek swelling give rise to frog face deformity

Explanation of other options:

Antrochoanal polyp (Option B): While this also presents as a unilateral nasal mass, it is an inflammatory polyp that is typically pale and avascular. It causes nasal obstruction but does not typically cause profuse bleeding. On CT, it opacifies and expands the maxillary sinus ostium, but does not cause the characteristic bony bowing seen in JNA.

Rhinoscleroma (Option C): This is a chronic granulomatous bacterial infection caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It leads to hard, nodular infiltrations ("woody" feel) of the nasal mucosa, not a distinct globular, vascular mass.

Rhinosporidiosis (Option D): This is a chronic fungal infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi that presents as a friable, polypoidal, "strawberry-like" mass that bleeds easily on touch, but it does not cause the specific bony erosion pattern of JNA.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with significant nasal trauma after a fall. Examination reveals a deviated nasal pyramid, and palpation confirms crepitus and mobility of the nasal bones. A lateral nasal bone X-ray confirms a displaced nasal bone fracture. Which of the following instruments is specifically designed for the closed reduction of a displaced nasal bone fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Walsham forceps are specifically designed for closed reduction of nasal bone fractures.

  • They have a straight, flat design with rubber/silicone protection on the blades to prevent mucosal trauma.
  • Straight, flat design with rubber/silicone protection on blades to prevent mucosal trauma.
  • One thin, straight blade is inserted intranasally under the depressed bone; the wider, padded blade is placed externally over the bone.
  • By closing the forceps, the surgeon grips, disimpacts, and elevates the fractured fragment into the correct position.

Explanation of other options:

Tilley's forceps (Option A): These are dressing forceps used for packing the nasal cavity with gauze or removing foreign bodies and crusts. They are not designed to manipulate bone.

Luc's forceps (Option B): These are double-action forceps primarily used in sinus surgery, such as the Caldwell-Luc operation, for removing diseased mucosa, polyps, or sinus tissue from the maxillary sinus. They are not used for nasal bone reduction.

Bayonet forceps (Option D): These are fine, angled forceps used for delicate manipulation, dressing, or packing deep within the nasal cavity. Their shape keeps the surgeon's hand out of the line of sight, but they lack the strength for bone reduction.

choices.text: It is used for effective ventilation for up to 6 hours
It is used to measure central venous pressure
It should be followed by a tracheostomy
The work of breathing is more than with bag-and-mask ventilation

questions.text: Following a building collapse, a male patient was brought to the emergency department with a copious amount of debris in the mouth, making endotracheal intubation impossible. The emergency procedure shown in the image was performed. Which of the following statements regarding this procedure is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image depicts a needle cricothyroidotomy, a rescue procedure for a "Can't Intubate, Can't Oxygenate" (CICO) airway emergency.

  • This is a temporary, life-saving measure that is not a definitive airway; therefore, it must be converted to a formal surgical airway, such as a tracheostomy, as soon as the patient is stabilized.
  • This procedure allows for emergency oxygenation but is inadequate for effective ventilation (CO2removal) and can only be used for a very short duration (30-45 minutes), not hours (Option A ruled out).
  • It accesses the airway through the cricothyroid membrane and has no connection to the central venous system, so it cannot be used to measure central venous pressure (Option B ruled out).
  • As it is performed to bypass a complete upper airway obstruction where bag-and-mask ventilation has failed, it dramatically decreases the work of breathing (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the casualty in an unresponsive state after consuming peanuts. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a child with foreign body aspiration, management depends on age and consciousness level:

  • In an infant <1 year: Alternate 5 back blows and 5 chest thrusts. (Option B ruled out)
  • In a child >1 year who is conscious but choking: Perform abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver). (Option A ruled out)
  • If the child becomes unresponsive: Begin basic life support (BLS) with chest compressions. This helps dislodge the foreign body by generating intrathoracic pressure, while also providing circulatory support.
  • Endotracheal intubation is not first-line because airway obstruction must be relieved before attempting intubation. (Option D ruled out)

Thus, in this case of a 3-year-old, unresponsive child, the immediate management is chest compressions.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female smoker presents with a long history of hoarseness of voice, difficulty swallowing, and difficulty breathing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal cancer and underwent surgical management. The post-operative picture is shown below. Which of the following surgeries was most likely performed on the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a permanent end tracheostomy, which is the definitive result of a total laryngectomy.

Indications of total laryngectomy:

  • Advanced laryngeal cancer (e.g., T4a stage with thyroid cartilage invasion).
  • Stage 3 or 4a tumours in patients unfit for chemoradiation.
  • Recurrent tumours after previous treatments.
  • Bilateral arytenoid involvement affects vocal cord mobility.

Permanent End Tracheostomy (Post-Total Laryngectomy)

  • Seen after total laryngectomy, performed for advanced laryngeal cancers when organ preservation is not feasible.
  • Entire larynx (including vocal cords, thyroid cartilage, and cricoid cartilage) is removed.
  • Pharynx is closed and the trachea is brought forward and sutured to the skin, creating a permanent stoma for breathing. This permanently separates the airway from the digestive tract.
  • Patients lose natural voice production, and require voice rehabilitation (esophageal speech, tracheoesophageal puncture, or electronic larynx).

Explanation of Other Options:

Partial laryngectomy (Option A): Involves removal of part of the larynx (e.g., hemilaryngectomy, supraglottic laryngectomy) with preservation of voice and no permanent tracheostomy. The picture does not match.

Standard tracheostomy (Option C): Involves creation of a temporary opening in the trachea for airway access. The upper airway remains intact, and tracheostomy tubes are usually present, unlike the permanent end stoma seen here.

Percutaneous tracheostomy (Option D): Minimally invasive tracheostomy done at the bedside, temporary and not equivalent to laryngectomy. It does not result in permanent separation of airway and digestive tract.
